howToPlay.title: How to Play Yaygara?
howToPlay.description: Yaygara is a fun party game for 4 to 16 players, blending elements of taboo and charades. The game is played in person by passing a single device from hand to hand.
howToPlay.goalDescription:
The game is played with at least two teams. Players take turns describing random words from a deck to their teammates within a set time limit to earn points.
‚Ä¢ 1-star (easy) words: 1 point
‚Ä¢ 2-star (medium) words: 2 points
‚Ä¢ 3-star (hard) words: 3 points
The game consists of 3 rounds. The same words are used in each round, but the rules for describing them get progressively harder. The team with the highest score at the end of all rounds wins.
howToPlay.seatingDescription: Since the game is played on a single device, it is passed from hand to hand to the next team's narrator after each turn. For a smooth rotation, it is recommended that players from different teams sit next to each other in a circle. This arrangement ensures the game moves quickly and stays fun.
howToPlay.flowDescription: Teams and team players take turns. When a player's time runs out, the turn passes to the next team's narrator. Each round is played until all words in the deck are correctly guessed. When a round is complete, you move to the next round using the same deck. For this reason, listen closely and don't give spoilers while the other team is describing! Those same words will come back to you as potential points later.
howToPlay.round1Description: Describe the word using any words, sounds, or gestures you like. Important: You cannot say the word itself, any part of it, its rhymes, or its translation in another language. If you're struggling, you can read the hint text directly below the card.
howToPlay.round2Description: This time, you can only use a single word as a clue. No gestures, facial expressions, or body language allowed. Choose your word wisely, as all words from Round 1 are back in play.
howToPlay.round3Description: Speaking and making sounds are forbidden! Act out the word using only gestures, facial expressions, and body language. All words are used together one last time.
howToPlay.passingDescription: Couldn't describe a word? No problem! You can pass as many times as you like. Passed words will reappear later in the round. If you accidentally pass or mark a word as correct, you can use the button that appears in the middle to undo the action.
howToPlay.bonusTimeDescription: If your team guesses all the words in a round with more than 3 seconds left, you start the next round immediately with that remaining time! Fast players get the advantage.

about.title: Yaygara
about.intro: Yaygara was developed by Mert S. Kaplan, inspired by classic games like Taboo, Charades, and Makara. It is free and ad-free. It works even without an internet connection. Plus, with AI support, you can create your own word decks and never get bored.
about.purpose:
The goal of the game is not only to entertain but also to help people improve their self-expression skills, strengthen social bonds, and learn new words along the way.
In other words, both brain exercise and fun! üß†‚ú®

In the software process, in addition to manual coding, I received intensive support from large language models such as Gemini, Grok, and ChatGPT in the planning, coding and debugging phases.
about.outro: A little human intelligence, a little artificial intelligence, lots of code and the result: Yaygara! Enjoy, everyone.

aiModal.title: Create Your Own Deck
aiModal.description: You can prepare your own word deck for Yaygara in seconds with the help of artificial intelligence. Edit the prompt template below as you wish (first 5 lines are enough) and choose an LLM to create your deck. You can save the resulting JSON output and upload it to the application.
aiModal.defaultPrompt:
Words/phrases to produce: 48
Deck language: English
Difficulty level: Medium
Deck name: 
Must-include words: 

Yaygara is a word game that is a mix of taboo and charades. Prepare a word deck for this game. Use the information above and the guidelines below as a basis.
The expressions in the deck can be single words or phrases. Words should be in the majority. (Example: kiss, astronaut, jewelry, frame, fault line, butterfly effect.) The "Must-include words" specified above should be in the deck and these words/phrases should be a reference for approximately 15 percent of the other words/phrases produced.
A difficulty (difficulty) value should be determined for each word and expressed as numbers 1, 2, and 3.
1 (Easy): Expressions that are frequently encountered in daily life and can be easily explained with gestures and facial expressions.
2 (Medium): Expressions that require cultural knowledge and indirect narration.
3 (Hard): Complex, cultural, intellectual, ironic, or deep-sounding, difficult words.
Apart from the words/phrases, there should also be a difficulty level for the deck as a whole. The difficulty level of the deck should be expressed with the English words easy, medium, and hard. For decks with medium difficulty, the difficulty level distribution of the words/phrases should be approximately: Easy 50%, medium 40%, hard 10%. For easy decks, it should be approximately: easy 60%, medium 35%, hard 5%; and for hard decks: easy 30%, medium 50%, hard 20%.
There should be a single-sentence, short but descriptive hint (hint) for each word. The hint should not contain the word itself or words from the same root (Example: You cannot say "Eye" for "Glasses"); it should contain a short and clear definition that makes it easier for players to reach the correct answer. (Example: You cannot use the expression "Lentil and bulgur meatballs" in the hint for "Lentil Meatballs". Because it contains the words lentil and meatballs. Instead, you can say "A type of dish made by giving shape to boiled legumes by hand".)
Words can be from topics such as: Popular culture, mythology, technology, idioms, slang, science, history, politics, art, literature, cinema, philosophy, geography, plants, sexuality, military, law, astrology, sports, hobbies, fictional characters, 90s, computer games, foreign TV series, etc.

If the deck name is not determined, determine a unique, short, and catchy deck name (name) suitable for the general theme of the words produced. The deck name should be a distinctive name. Create an ID based on the deck name. The ID should consist of lowercase letters and English characters. Use a hyphen (-) instead of a space and add the two-character language code and json extension at the end (example: complex-minds.en.json, dark-adventure.en.json, or love-is-all.en.json).
The output should be in valid JSON format only. After creating the word deck, ask the user if they want to make any edits. Include the JSON file as a downloadable at the bottom of your response.

JSON format and example:
{
  "id": "love-is-all.en",
  "name": "Love is All",
  "language": "en",
  "difficulty": "medium",
  "words": [
    {
      "term": "Platonic",
      "hint": "An emotional bond experienced internally without being reciprocated.",
      "difficulty": 1
    }
  ]
}
